title: Ticket #6857: Excessive CPU usage by GPU Monitor
description:
Users are reporting excessive GPU usage by the monitor, now that it's been turned on by default; see below. The first thing to do is to disable the GPU monitor by default; it's much easier for user to add back, if it was working for them, then to remove.

Alexander Antoniades wrote: 
I have a consumer gpu server from Advanced HPC which has 8 1080ti GPUs and
2 E5-2603 Xeons (6 cores each).

The cpu usage of GPUs_MONITOR seems a little high for sitting at idle.
condor    2165 66.9  0.0  26460  6844 ?        R    Jan08 793:42 GPUs_MONITOR

This is with Condor 8.8 on Ubuntu 18.04.1 LTS.

Todd L Miller replied: 

I would just try killing it (this will, of course, cause bogus GPU usage
numbers to be reported) and seeing it the problem re-occurs.

Alexander Antoniades: 

I killed the process and cpu usage is the same.

USER       PID %CPU %MEM    VSZ   RSS TTY      STAT START   TIME COMMAND
condor   26313 67.1  0.0  26460  6772 ?        S    15:39  14:44 GPUs_MONITOR

Here's a the summery of a quick strace if that helps.

root@gpu2:~# sort condor_gpu.txt |uniq -c
    793 getpid()                                = 26313
  39637 ioctl(0, _IOC(_IOC_READ|_IOC_WRITE, 0x46, 0x2a, 0x20),
0x7ffd1e446f30) = 0
    397 ioctl(0, _IOC(_IOC_READ|_IOC_WRITE, 0x46, 0x2a, 0x20),
0x7ffd1e447110) = 0
      1 ioctl(0, _IOC(_IOC_READ|_IOC_WRITE, 0x46, 0x2a, 0x20) <detached ...>
    396 ioctl(0, _IOC(_IOC_READ|_IOC_WRITE, 0x46, 0x4a, 0xb0),
0x7ffd1e4536a0) = 0
     49 nanosleep({tv_sec=0, tv_nsec=100000000}, NULL) = 0
      1 restart_syscall(<... resuming interrupted nanosleep ...>) = 0
     12 write(1, "SlotMergeConstraint = StringList"..., 135) = 135
      6 write(1, "SlotMergeConstraint = StringList"..., 136) = 136
      6 write(1, "SlotMergeConstraint = StringList"..., 139) = 139

Bert DeKnuydt confirmed the problem, and supplied some more information: 

strace reports it is mainly in

nanosleep({tv_sec=0, tv_nsec=100000000}

which is to be expected.  For the rest I see zillions
(well, 4200 per second more or less), of these

ioctl(0, _IOC(_IOC_READ|_IOC_WRITE, 0x46, 0x2a, 0x20), 0x7ffe74c56e10) = 0

Don't know what this exactly is doing.

B. Baumeier agreed as well, saying: 

For what it's worth, for me it's not as high but about 8%. Which seems still
a bit more than it should.

and also (after being asked if the GPUs were busy): 

*) This was on an totally idle system. On all 9 test machines I have 6 to 9%
CPU consistently.
*) 'perf top' shows that it is indeed the nvml library; more in detail: (to
5% only)

[root@postel ~]# perf top -p 1254
  32.47%  [kernel]                [k] _nv031472rm
  19.52%  [kernel]                [k] pci_conf1_read
   5.05%  [kernel]                [k] _raw_spin_lock_irqsave
   4.28%  [kernel]                [k] _nv033593rm
   1.59%  [kernel]                [k] _nv007572rm
   1.30%  [kernel]                [k] _nv034648rm
[...]

This is with libnvidia-ml.so.415.25 on a GeForce GTX 960

Michael Pelletier analyszed the ioctl: 

>  39637 ioctl(0, _IOC(_IOC_READ|_IOC_WRITE, 0x46, 0x2a, 0x20),

File descriptor 0 should be stdin, right? Odd that they've got a "write"
associated with it. The second argument appears to be an expansion of this
macro from ioctl.h:

#define _IOWR(type,nr,size)
_IOC(_IOC_READ|_IOC_WRITE,(type),(nr),(_IOC_TYPECHECK(size)))

The type is 'F' from the ioctl-numbers.txt file, if I'm understanding this
correctly:
https://github.com/torvalds/linux/blob/master/Documentation/ioctl/ioctl-numb
er.txt

... which as you would expect is associated with video:

'F'     20      drivers/video/fsl-diu-fb.h      conflict!
'F'     20      drivers/video/intelfb/intelfb.h conflict!
'F'     20      linux/ivtvfb.h          conflict!
'F'     20      linux/matroxfb.h        conflict!
'F'     20      drivers/video/aty/atyfb_base.c  conflict!
'F'     00-0F   video/da8xx-fb.h        conflict!
'F'     80-8F   linux/arcfb.h           conflict!
'F'     DD      video/sstfb.h           conflict!

... and the "nr" value is dec42 (heh) which is a sequence number, and a
"long double" type is a native one which has a size of 16 bytes.

Is the nouveau driver being used, or the NVIDIA-supplied driver?

Alexander Antoniades replied: 

On the machine in question I believe we are running the nvidia drivers.
... 
root@gpu2:~# lsmod | grep nv
nvidia_uvm            757760  4
nvidia_drm             40960  0
nvidia_modeset       1114112  1 nvidia_drm
nvidia              14364672  632 nvidia_modeset,nvidia_uvm

Michael Pelletier: 

Your driver version is 390.87, so of course the first thing the NVIDIA tech
is going to ask is whether anyone has tried the 396.44 release.

Alexander Antoniades: 

I plan on updating these servers next week. It looks like I can pull 3.96
from the graphics-driver ppa so I will update them when I can coordinate
with the users and I'll see if that resolves the issue, and report back.
